abstract.text: A graphics renderer for creating Core Graphics-backed images.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: You can use image renderers to accomplish drawing tasks, without having to handle configuration such as color depth and image scale, or manage Core Graphics contexts. You initialize an image renderer with parameters such as image output dimensions and format. You then use one or more of the drawing functions to render images that share these properties.
To render an image:
Optionally, create a
object to specify nondefault parameters the renderer should use to create its context.
Instantiate a
object, providing the dimensions of the output image and a format object. The renderer uses default values for the current device if you don’t provide format object, as demonstrated in
Choose one of the rendering methods depending on the output you desire:
returns a
object;
returns a JPEG-encoded
object; and
returns a PNG-encoded
object.
Execute your chosen method, providing Core Graphics drawing instructions as the closure argument, as shown in
demonstrates some of the more advanced rendering features you can use in your drawing instructions.
Optionally, you can use Core Graphics drawing code within the drawing instructions you provide to the rendering method, as shown in

After initializing an image renderer, you can use it to draw multiple images with the same configuration. An image renderer keeps a cache of Core Graphics contexts, so reusing the same renderer can be more efficient than creating new renderers.
Create an image renderer, providing the size of the output image:
You can instead use one of the other
initializers to specify a renderer format (
) in addition to the size. This allows you to configure the underlying Core Graphics context for wide color and retina images.
If you don’t provide a format, the renderer uses the
format, which creates a context best suited for the current device.

content.text: Creating an image with an image renderer

inlineContent.text: Use the
method to create an image (

object) with an image renderer. This method takes a closure that represents the drawing actions. Within this closure, the renderer creates a Core Graphics context using the parameters provided during renderer initialization, and sets this Core Graphics context to be the current context.
The drawing actions closure takes a single argument of type
. This provides access to some high-level drawing functions, such as
, through the
superclass.

In addition to the

The utility methods on

value. This value determines how to combine the pixel values when painting.
This code draws a second square, using a blend mode of multiply. The following image shows the result.
The

abstract.text: Compositing operations for images.
A Quartz 2D drawing environment.
Paints the area of the ellipse that fits inside the provided rectangle, using the fill color in the current graphics state.
A byte buffer in memory.

abstract.text: A closure for drawing an image.
Creates an image from a set of drawing instructions.
Creates an image renderer with the specified bounds and format.
Creates an image renderer for drawing images of the specified size.
Creates an image renderer with the specified size and format.
Creates a JPEG-encoded image from a set of drawing instructions.
Creates a PNG-encoded image from a set of drawing instructions.
The drawing environment for an image renderer.
A set of drawing attributes that represents the configuration of an image renderer context.
A graphics renderer for creating PDFs.
The drawing environment for a PDF renderer.
A set of drawing attributes that represents the configuration of a PDF renderer context.
An abstract base class for creating graphics renderers.
The base class for the drawing environments for graphics renderers.
The underlying Core Graphics context.
Paints a rectangular area with the currently selected fill color.
A set of drawing attributes that represents the configuration of a graphics renderer context.
Returns a format that represents the highest fidelity that the current device supports.
An object that manages image data in your app.

abstract.text: The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
